channel.title: I should be cooking but

item.title: I should be cooking but
item.dc:creator: @Slave_Scyth Slave Scyth
item.description:
@Slave_Scyth wrote:

[quote=“Graham, post:13, topic:386562”][quote author=Slave Scyth link=topic=482328.msg3535779#msg3535779 date=1300556951]

Instead I am screwing around with CSS and failing hard, Basically I want my table rows on this page (http://silabsoft.org/itemdb/index.php?content=Clean%20Herbs) to have 34px height but they seem to be doing whatever they want.

my CSS:

.ProfitTable tr{
	height: 34;
}

ProfitTable is the class id of the div the table is sitting in. Any reason as to why this is not working?
[/quote]CSS requires a unit for sizing elements. Append ‘px’ to that ‘34’ like Saphire said.

And I’d recommend putting the height element on a TD (rather than TR) in the HTML, versus the CSS (In my opinion, at least if it’s only one row, it’s cleaner). The other TD’s in that row will resize themselves to whatever the largest one is.

One of the main points of CSS is to separate style and markup…[/quote]That doesn’t mean that HTML can’t make things a bit less messy at times.

If you’re only trying to edit a single element of a page with a height, I would never think it was worth it to type up twice or triple as much as you could.

Either way, my suggestion still stands. My HTML recommendation was, as said, a recommendation. What I suggested would work either way.

Read full topic

@Graham wrote:

[quote=“Slave Scyth, post:12, topic:386562”][quote author=Miss Silabsoft link=topic=482328.msg3532296#msg3532296 date=1300271441]
Instead I am screwing around with CSS and failing hard, Basically I want my table rows on this page (http://silabsoft.org/itemdb/index.php?content=Clean%20Herbs) to have 34px height but they seem to be doing whatever they want.

my CSS:

.ProfitTable tr{
	height: 34;
}

ProfitTable is the class id of the div the table is sitting in. Any reason as to why this is not working?
[/quote]CSS requires a unit for sizing elements. Append ‘px’ to that ‘34’ like Saphire said.

And I’d recommend putting the height element on a TD (rather than TR) in the HTML, versus the CSS (In my opinion, at least if it’s only one row, it’s cleaner). The other TD’s in that row will resize themselves to whatever the largest one is.

[/quote]

One of the main points of CSS is to separate style and markup…

my CSS:

.ProfitTable tr{
	height: 34;
}

ProfitTable is the class id of the div the table is sitting in. Any reason as to why this is not working?[/quote]CSS requires a unit for sizing elements. Append ‘px’ to that ‘34’ like Saphire said.

And I’d recommend putting the height element on a TD (rather than TR) in the HTML, versus the CSS (In my opinion, at least if it’s only one row, it’s cleaner). The other TD’s in that row will resize themselves to whatever the largest one is.

item.title: I should be cooking but
item.dc:creator: @NewbieNewty Newty
item.description:
@NewbieNewty wrote:

[quote=“Saphire`, post:6, topic:386562”]Newty, that wouldn’t read the class needed.

.ProfitTable tr{ height:34px; }

should work, or:

.ProfitTable tr{ th { height:34px; } }[/quote]

I pasted the code straight from w3 it’s obviously implied that she knows what to change it to.

Read full topic

item.title: I should be cooking but
item.dc:creator: @Saphire1 Saphire`
item.description:

Newty, that wouldn’t read the class needed.

.ProfitTable tr{ height:34px; }

should work, or:

.ProfitTable tr{ th { height:34px; } }

item.title: I should be cooking but
item.dc:creator: @NewbieNewty Newty
item.description:
@NewbieNewty wrote:

http://www.w3schools.com/css/css_table.asp

table 
{
width:100%;
}
th
{
height:50px;
}

If this doesn’t work then it’s probably an error on your part that you haven’t noticed.

Read full topic
